title: 111_hr230
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" and includes provisions for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" authorizes Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing and new mortgages on single-family housing, as per established policies by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. Lenders must meet specific requirements for the enterprises to consider purchasing the mortgages. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 allows Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to buy qualified mortgages from lenders based on set criteria by the Director. If the enterprises determine that a mortgage meets the qualified criteria, they commit to purchasing it. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 allows Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase qualified mortgages from lenders based on set criteria. The Director requires the enterprises to establish a procedure for advance commitments for the purchase of qualified mortgages. A qualified mortgage is defined as either a qualified refinancing mortgage or a qualified new mortgage. Qualified mortgages are defined as either qualified refinancing mortgages or qualified new mortgages, with specific requirements for the property subject to the mortgage. The mortgage must be for a one- to four-family dwelling, including condos or cooperative housing. The mortgagor must live in the property as their main residence. The loan amount must be used to pay off existing first mortgage debt. Refinancing of the principal loan amount secured by the mortgage must be used to pay off existing first mortgage debt on the same property originated before January 1, 2008. The mortgage must be for a one- to four-family dwelling, and the mortgagor must reside in the property. The mortgage for refinancing must be used to pay off existing first mortgage debt on a one- to four-family dwelling where the mortgagor resides. The new mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term of not less than 30 years and not more than 40 years. The mortgage for refinancing must have a term of not less than 30 years and not more than 40 years from the beginning of the amortization. The mortgage must meet underwriting standards set by the Director and waive prepayment penalties. The qualified new mortgage must waive prepayment penalties and meet specific terms outlined in the section. The term "qualified new mortgage" refers to a mortgage that meets certain requirements, including specific terms outlined in the section. The mortgage must be used to purchase the property and originated on or after the enactment of this Act. Each enterprise is required to adhere to exceptions to underwriting standards. The mortgage must be a qualified new mortgage originated on or after the enactment of this Act. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. Securitization of qualified mortgages purchased by enterprises under this section is required, with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury to issue and sell securities based on these mortgages. Securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. Securities issued under this subsection by enterprises must have maturities, interest rates, and may be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. Securities are exempt to the same extent as direct obligations or guaranteed obligations. Securities issued by an enterprise under this subsection are deemed exempt securities, similar to those guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages set aside must always be sufficient for timely principal and interest payments. Securities issued under this subsection must have adequate mortgages set aside for timely principal and interest payments. The securities are not guaranteed by the United States and do not constitute a debt or obligation of the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility to provide credit to enterprises at interest rates similar to Treasury securities, with securities clearly stating they are not guaranteed by the United States. The Federal Reserve System will create a credit facility to offer credit to enterprises at interest rates comparable to Treasury securities, with similar terms. The enterprises will no longer be required to purchase mortgages after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

This Act defines key terms such as Director (referring to the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency), Enterprise (referring to the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation), and Secretary (referring to the Secretary of the Treasury).
